title: Diabetic Foot Ulcer in a Retired Carpenter: The Case of Mr. Thomas Jenkins
clinical_history: Mr. Thomas Jenkins is a 68-year-old retired carpenter with a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presented to the outpatient clinic with a non-healing ulcer located on the plantar aspect of his left foot, just proximal to the heads of the first and second metatarsals. The patient reports noticing a small blister three weeks ago, which has since developed into an ulcer approximately 2.5 cm in diameter. He describes increased discomfort when walking and states that there is now visible redness, surrounding callus, and some serous discharge. He denies any fevers or chills but notes mild swelling in the left foot. Mr. Jenkins admits to inconsistent glycemic control and often walks barefoot at home. He also acknowledges reduced sensation in both feet for several years.

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged walking, standing, wearing ill-fitting shoes, contact with hard flooring, and increased activity levels aggravate symptoms.

easing_factors: Resting, offloading the affected foot (using a soft slipper or when seated with the foot elevated), daily saline dressings, and mild pain relief (acetaminophen).
past_history: No prior history of foot ulcers, but reports corns and calluses in the same region over the past 5 years. Denies prior lower limb fractures or surgeries.
medical_history: Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and mild diabetic neuropathy (bilateral). HbA1c consistently >8% for several years.
medications: Metformin, glimepiride, lisinopril, simvastatin, acetaminophen (as needed for pain).
personal_history: Lifelong non-smoker, moderate alcohol use (3-4 beers/week), married, lives with spouse in a single-level home. Retired 8 years ago. Diet is high in carbohydrates with erratic meal patterns. Minimal exercise due to persistent foot discomfort.
imaging: Pending X-ray of left foot to rule out underlying osteomyelitis and assess bony involvement (forefoot, particularly first and second metatarsals). Doppler studies previously normal, no evidence of significant arterial disease.
